occurrences.line_text: As fresh as when it first was planted in the soyle.
But there was planted, or grew naturall:
Planted in earth, being deriu'd at furst
And manners mylde were planted naturall;
But if few plants preseru'd through heauenly ayd,
And with their boughes the gentle plants did beat.
The one vpon his hardy head him plast,
Hath thus transformd, and plast in open plaines,
And priuie spials plast in all his way,
Whenas they spide a goodly castle, plast
They in another great round vessell plast,
And in long Alba plast his throne apart,
Then the braue Maid, which all this while was plast,
There were rent robes, and broken scepters plast,
As seeming plast in sole felicity:
Was in the middest plast among them all;
That fayld the trust, which she in him had plast,
Hath now forgot, where he was plast of yore,
His bodie was her thrall, his hart was freely plast.
That euen the Temple, wherein she was plast,
Who seeing, in what daunger he was plast,
And wish my lot were plast in such felicitie.
And plast on his, he did it soone displace,
To haue her knight into her schoolehouse plaste,
In which accord the Prince was also plaste,
And plaste for pleasure nigh that forrest syde:
Before that they in blisse amongst the Gods were plaste.
And by the altars side her selfe to slumber plaste.
It was an hill plaste in an open plaine,
To saue her chylde, which in misfortunes mouth was plaste.
The fruitfull Oliue, and the Platane round,
That with their force they perst both plate and maile,
Disarmed all of yron-coted Plate,
He smote so manly on his shoulder plate,
Ne plate, ne male could ward so mighty throwes,
That seem'd both shield & plate it would haue riued;
Now Bacchus fruit out of the siluer plate
That neither plate nor mayle, whereas their powre
That glauncing on her shoulder plate, it bit
So forth he came all in a cote of plate,
All armed in a cote of yron plate,
Like plated coate of steele, so couched neare,
Vpon the brim of his brode plated shield,
Were wont to riue steele plates, and helmets hew,
Some in round plates withouten moniment;
That all his mayle yriv'd, and plates yrent,
Rashing off helmes, and ryuing plates a sonder,
They hew'd their helmes, and plates asunder brake,
Thereby a Christall streame did gently play,
And made him dreame of loues and lustfull play,
She soone left off her mirth and wanton play,
Where they in idle pompe, or wanton play,
For loue of me leaue off this dreadfull play;
That drops of bloud thence like a well did play;
On which the thrise three learned Ladies play
Their wanton sports and childish mirth did play,
Did come too neare, and with his talants play,
Her curious skill, the warbling notes to play,
Als in her lap a louely babe did play
But with the wooddie Nymphes when she did play,
The saluage beastes in her victorious play,
But more enfierced through his currish play,
A gentle streame, whose murmuring waue did play
That round about him dissolute did play
Or to behold the water worke, and play
But Guyons angry blade so fierce did play
With his faire mother he him dights to play,
The Goddesse pleased with his wanton play,
Vpon the Bulwarkes cruelly did play,
But for she saw him bent to cruell play,
With whom he meant to make his sport & courtly play.
And full of subtile sophismes, which do play
To sorrow huge she turnd her former play,
How diuersly loue doth his pageants play,
And mortall miseries doth make her play.
But who that smites it, mars his ioyous play,
And taught the carefull Mariner to play,
For she does ioy to play emongst her peares,
Who all the night did minde his ioyous play:
In signe of silence, as to heare a play,
And when they ceast, it gan againe to play,
Now cease your worke, and at your pleasure play:
That masked Mock-knight was their sport and play.
To ioyous feast and other gentle play;
She with the pleasant Graces wont to play.
Of a fresh streame I with that Elfe did play,
Sweet springs, in which a thousand Nymphs did play;
The waters play and pleasant lands appeare,
They all doe learne to play the Paramours;
Then doe the saluage beasts begin to play
Ten thousand fishes play, and decke his pleasant streame.
So did the villaine to her prate and play,
To be aueng'd of their vnknightly play.
For both were wondrous practicke in that play,
To pitty him that list to play the foole:
The whylest at pleasure she mote sport and play;
Or with the Graces there to play and sport;
Where left, he went, and his owne false part playd,
But weend it was my loue, with whom he playd.
And eke emongst them litle Cupid playd
For weet ye well of all, that euer playd
Yet playd Pasiphaï¿½ a more monstrous part,
And heauy tydings heard, whereas she playd
The sunne-beames bright vpon her body playd,
The good man selfe, which then the Porter playd,
Whiles thus on earth great Ioue these pageaunts playd,
Wrought with wilde Antickes, which their follies playd,
The whiles shril trompets & loud clarions sweetly playd.
Which through the tre[m]bling leaues full gently playes
Aside, with faire Adonis playes his wanton parts.
And his true loue faire Psyche with him playes,
The mighty Mars, to learne his wanton playes:
In louely wise, and sleepes, and sports, and playes;
Which here with thee doe make their pleasant playes?
Go find some other play-fellowes, mine own sweet boy.
Playing their sports, that ioyd her to behold,
And Titan playing on the eastern streames,
To fly about, playing their wanton toyes,
The faire Poeana playing on a Rote,
Art playing second natures part, supplyed it.
But like to Angels playing heauenly toyes;
Who playing on his harpe, vnto him drew
So went he playing on the watery plaine.
Amongst his peres playing his childish sport:
Playing on shaumes and trumpets, that from hence
Playing his pages part, as he had beene
Playing on pypes, and caroling apace,
Of a shrill pipe he playing heard on hight,
And to him playnd, how that false winged boy,
And playnd of grieuous outrage, which he red
Which earst to you I playnd: for neither may
And left inglorious on the vanquisht playne,
Yet is as nigh his end, as he that most doth playne.
By miracle, not yet appearing playne,
The playnes all waste and emptie did appeare:
His fleecie flocke vpon the playnes around,
For he regarded neither playnt nor teare,
He neuer meant with words, but swords to plead his right.
In face of iudgement he their right would plead,
For truth is strong, her rightfull cause to plead,
Rose many aduocates for her to plead:
And lastly Griefe did plead, and many teares forth powre.
But she thereto nould plead, nor answere ought
To heare the piteous beast pleading her plaintiffe cause.
And hearing pleas of people meane and base.
Who with sweet pleasance and bold blandishment
That turned all her pleasance to a scoffing game.
After them went Displeasure and Pleasance,
Leaping like wanton kids in pleasant Spring.
Both plaine, and pleasant to be walked in,
Into a pleasant dale, that lowly lay
For she in pleasant purpose did abound,
Of malice in the calme of pleasant womankind.
The flowres, the fields, and all that pleasant growes,
Till they arriued in that pleasant Ile,
And all though pleasant, yet she made much more:
Does yeeld vnto his foe a pleasant victory.
Which seemd so sweet and pleasant to the eye,
As faint through heat, or dight to pleasant sin,
But all those pleasant bowres and Pallace braue,
Where was their dwelling, in a pleasant glade,
All other pleasant places doth excell,
There was a pleasant arbour, not by art,
Yet should it be a pleasant tale, to tell
She with the pleasant Graces wont to play.
More hard for hungry steed t'abstaine from pleasant lare.
The onely pleasant and delightfull place,
And here and there were pleasant arbors pight,
The waters play and pleasant lands appeare,
Their pleasant friskes, and loath their wonted food;
Ten thousand fishes play, and decke his pleasant streame.
And Sture, that parteth with his pleasant floods
The pleasant Boyne, the fishy fruitfull Ban,
And talk't of pleasant things, the night away to weare.
Charmes to the birds full many a pleasant lay,
And many pleasant trickes before her show,
Out of the pleasant soyle, and citties glad,
Of all that pleasant is to eare or eye,
Which here with thee doe make their pleasant playes?
The Oceans daughter, in this pleasant groue,
Heard sound through all the Pallace pleasantly,
Faire seemely pleasaunce each to other makes,
With pleasaunce of the breathing fields yfed
And bathe in pleasaunce of the ioyous shade,
Whose pleasaunce she him shew'd, and plentifull great store.
Her honest merth and pleasaunce to partake;
All pleasaunce was to them griefe and annoy:
His stubborne brest gan secret pleasaunce to embrace.
That can with melting pleasaunce mollifye
And pleasaunce of the place, the which was dight
Vnto a place, whose pleasaunce did appere
Her selfe to pleasaunce, vsed to resort
And rapt with pleasaunce, wist not what to weene;
Strowed with pleasauns, whose faire grassy ground
Or like that pleasaunt Mount, that is for ay
And on the other side a pleasaunt groue
Foreby a riuer in a pleasaunt dale,
That twixt them both a pleasaunt port they made,
Their pleasaunt tunes they sweetly thus applide;
More sweet and holesome, then the pleasaunt hill
And pleasaunt bord, they past forth on their way,
Shew gladsome countenaunce nor pleasaunt glee:
The pleasaunt Bandon crownd with many a wood,
And pitty her sad plight, so chang'd from pleasaunt hew.
Whilst round about them pleasauntly did sing
So pleasauntly the hill with equall hight,
And pleasd them all with meete satietie,
She was well pleasd, and forth her damzels sent,
So be ye pleasd to pardon all amis.
That counsell pleasd: then Paridell did rise,
As though she wished to haue pleasd them all,
Of all her gifts, that pleasde each liuing sight,
And fed with words, that could not chuse but please,
To do none ill, if please ye not do well.
Good cause of mine excuse; that mote ye please
Vnseemely man to please faire Ladies eye;
Did her content to please their feeble eyes,
Ease after warre, death after life does greatly please.
Whom if ye please for to discouer plaine,
Each stroue to please, and others pleasure to fulfill.
Was ouercome of thing, that did him please;
Take what thou please of all this surplusage;
Diuerse delights they found them selues to please;
I will, if please you it discure, assay,
Whose wanton pleasures him too much did please.
Which if ye please, to yonder castle turne your gate.
But yet, if please ye listen to my lore,
But there mote find to please it selfe withall;
But if ye please, that I your cause decide,
Yet found no place, that could her liking please,
Which if ye please forgiue, I will therefore
But sith ye please, that both our blames shall die,
And further sayd; Ah Sir, but mote ye please,
Fashion'd to please the eies of them, that pas,
To please the best, and th'euill to embase.
Now tell, if please you, of the good successe,
Please it you Ladie, to vs to aread,
For all her paine, if please her make the priefe.
Somewhile with merry purpose fit to please,
And how to please the minds of good and ill,
Or learn'd the art to please, I doe not fynd.
But if ye please to lend me leaue a while,
And seeke to please, that now is counted wisemens threasure.
So pleased, did his wrathfull purpose faire appease.
That she well pleased was thence to amoue him farre.
The Goddesse pleased with his wanton play,
As pleased them to vse, that vse it might:
His feeling words her feeble sence much pleased,
And pleased with that seeming goodly-hed,
The which the powres to thee are pleased to reuele.
That counsell pleased well; so all yfere
It pleased well. So well they both agree;
That counsell pleased not Malbeccoes mind;
It pleased: so he did, Then they march forward braue.
That offer pleased all the company,
Therewith he rested, and well pleased was.
Well pleased with that doome was Sangliere,
There he did see, that pleased much his sight,
And Bellamour againe so well her pleased,
For that old man of pleasing wordes had store,
And th'others pleasing seruice to abate,
A pleasing vaine of glory vaine did find,
Did all she might, more pleasing to appeare.
And flowes in pleasures, and vaine pleasing toyes,
Such powre haue pleasing words: such is the might
Vnto thy bounteous baytes, and pleasing charmes,
Is sweet, and pleasing vnto liuing sense,
And semblaunce pleasing, more then naturall,
For all that pleasing is to liuing eare,
As in approuance of his pleasing words.
To feed her humour with his pleasing stile,
For pleasing words are like to Magick art,
To loue the semblant pleasing most your mind,
And pleasing toyes he would her entertaine,
At hand with humble pride, and pleasing guile,
And painefull pleasure turnes to pleasing paine.
Through false allurement of that pleasing baite,
And proud despight of his selfe pleasing mynd,
Or beare her on thy backe with pleasing payne,
Her pleasing tongue, that soone she pacifyde
Burnt in her loue, and with sweet pleasing payne
That twixt his pleasing tongue, and her faire hew,
And foorth they passe, with pleasure forward led,
And in her many troubles did most pleasure take.
Yet since thou bidst, thy pleasure shalbe donne.
Great pleasure mixt with pittifull regard,
Her blisse is all in pleasure and delight,
The strong through pleasure soonest falles, the weake through smart.
Their minds to pleasure, & their mouthes to dainty fare.
But poured out in pleasure and delight;
And gazers sense with double pleasure fed,
In this wilde forrest, where no pleasure is,
And swim in pleasure, which thou here doest mis;
Each stroue to please, and others pleasure to fulfill.
In ioyous pleasure, then in grieuous paine:
Ne wind and weather at his pleasure call:
Great pleasure had those stranger knights, to see
Yet secret pleasure did offence empeach,
Where Pleasure dwelles in sensuall delights,
Rather for pleasure, then for battery or fight.
Quite molten into lust and pleasure lewd;
And plaste for pleasure nigh that forrest syde:
Withouten pleasure: ne her need implore
For here all plentie, and all pleasure flowes,
And reape sweet pleasure of the wanton boy;
Pleasure, that doth both gods and men aggrate,
Pleasure, the daughter of Cupid and Psyche late.
Then her owne daughter Pleasure, to whom shee
Her lothsome pleasure there to satisfye;
In hope vnto my pleasure to haue won;
And painefull pleasure turnes to pleasing paine.
And gaue her leaue at pleasure forth to passe.
Of huge affection, did in pleasure melt,
Now cease your worke, and at your pleasure play:
And chaung'd at pleasure for those impes of thine.
As if he naught but peace and pleasure ment,
Walkt through the wood, for pleasure, or for need;
That when your pleasure is to deeme aright,
For ought will from his greedie pleasure spare:
To rest him selfe, and solace in soft pleasure
So eke lou'd Blandamour, but yet at pleasure
In such luxurious plentie of all pleasure,
She is the nourse of pleasure and delight,
But thou the same for pleasure didst prepayre.
There leaue we them in pleasure and repast,
And in anothers losse great pleasure take,
So downe he sate, and with delightfull pleasure
Abstaine from pleasure, and restraine your will,
Thereof by force to take their beastly pleasure.
The whylest at pleasure she mote sport and play;
Ne ought there wanted, which for pleasure might
And prises to them placed at their pleasure,
Her chast hart had subdewd, to learne Dame pleasures toy.
And made the vassall of his pleasures vilde.
Then serue his Ladies loue, and wast in pleasures vayne.
His heart did seeme to melt in pleasures manifold.
With pleasures poisoned baytes.
Neither to melt in pleasures whot desire,
And learne from pleasures poyson to abstaine:
To pleasures pallace; it may soone be spide,
And idle pleasures in his[her] Bowre of Blisse,
And flowes in pleasures, and vaine pleasing toyes,
Him to aggrate, and greatest pleasures shew;
With false delights, and fild with pleasures vaine,
Refuse such fruitlesse toile, and present pleasures chuse.
And told that gardins pleasures in their caroling.
That her sweet peace and pleasures did annoy,
Her selfe to shroud, and pleasures to entreat.
Whose wanton pleasures him too much did please.
Of feeling pleasures, with which day and night
And Pleasures porter was deuizd to bee,
In which all pleasures plenteously abound,
As Ladies wont, in pleasures wanton lap,
Ne tastest Princes pleasures, ne doest spred
With pleasures manifold.
From her sweet bowres, and beds with pleasures fraught:
Or be the vassall of her pleasures vile,
And timely seruice to her pleasures meet
In blessed Nectar, and pure Pleasures well,
He then did put, her pleasures lenger to partake.
Their spotlesse pleasures, and sweet loues content.
To tast of ioy, and to wont pleasures to retourne.
Such secret comfort, and such heauenly pleasures,
And prou'd the perfect pleasures, which doe grow
And also of the place, whose pleasures rare
Many graue persons, that against her pled;
And Nereus crownes with cups; his mates him pledg around.
But threw his gauntlet as a sacred pledge,
To loose, ne yet the warlike pledge to yield,
The sacred pledge of Christes Euangely;
And when so of his hand the pledge she raught,
Defil'd the pledge committed to thy trust?
The sacred pledge, which in his faith was left,
The pledge of faith, her hand engaged held,
Was grieued to restore the pledge, he did possesse.
The sacred pledge of peace and clemencie,
And eke as pledges firme, right hands together ioynd.
Was lincked, and by him had many pledges dere.
And sacred pledges he both gaue, and had,
With right hands plighted, pledges of good will.
Loe I for pledges leaue. So giue me leaue to rest.
And pledges; as the spoiles of my victorious games.
Three hundred pledges for my good desartes,
Would me refuse their pledges to afford,
And pledges pawnd the same to keepe a right,
On her they poured forth of plenteous horne;
Moued with pity of her plenteous teares.
With that he forth would poure so plenteous teares,
Next these the plenteous Ouse came far from land,
With the reuenue of her plenteous meedes:
Of which though present age doe plenteous seeme,
Which she perceiuing, did with plenteous teares
And nature me endu'd with plenteous dowre,
That heauenly grace so plenteously displayd;
In which all pleasures plenteously abound,
And plentie, which in all the land did grow;
For here all plentie, and all pleasure flowes,
In such luxurious plentie of all pleasure,
Whose pleasaunce she him shew'd, and plentifull great store.
Was poured forth with plentifull dispence,
That vertue should be plentifully found,
Whose wealth was want, whose ple[n]ty made him pore,
That of his plenty poured forth to all:
And of her plenty adde vnto their need:
That of my plenty poure out vnto all,
Abusd her plenty, and fat swolne encreace
Pourd out their plenty, without spight or spare:
Plenty of pearles to decke his dames withall,
That vnderneath his feet soone made a purple plesh.
On Phrygian Paris by Plexippus brooke,
And sternely bad him other businesse plie,
Yet Talus after them apace did plie,
In this sad plight, friendlesse, vnfortunate,
We may not chaunge (quoth he) this euil plight,
Sad Vna downe her laies in wearie plight,
His mournefull plight, is swallowd vp vnwares,
Whom when she found, as she him left in plight,
There dwell in perill of like painefull plight,
Can now deuise to quit a thrall from such a plight?
In their rude eyes vnworthie of so wofull plight.
Thy sad tongue cannot tell more heauy plight,
In pensiue plight, and sad perplexitie,
The roote of all your care, and wretched plight,
But she now weighing the decayed plight,
For neuer knight I saw in such misseeming plight.
Till he recouered had his late decayed plight.
And be partakers of their euill plight,
Who well acquainted with that commune plight,
And much asswag'd the passion of his plight,
For by the faith, which I to armes haue plight,
For thy appease your griefe and heauie plight,
And read, who hath ye wrought this shamefull plight.
Purfled vpon with many a folded plight,
When late he saw his Lord in heauy plight,
About her necke, or rings of rushes plight;
His owne deare Lord Pyrrochles, in sad plight,
To saue my Lord, in wretched plight forlore;
How euer, sure I rew his pitteous plight.
Mote I beseech to succour his sad plight,
That sith I armes and knighthood first did plight,
Close round about her tuckt with many a plight:
Who stird with pitty of the stressed plight
Till that the Prince seeing her wofull plight,
Into most deadly daunger and distressed plight.
Hauing their wearie limbes to perfect plight
And we your liege men faith vnto you plight.
Could find no rest in such perplexed plight,
What vncouth fit (said she) what euill plight
Tormenteth, and doth plonge in dolefull plight,
And eke himselfe mournd at their mournfull plight,
Lamenting his mishap and heauy plight;
To comfort me in my distressed plight?
And his foule sore reduced to faire plight:
And came at last in weary wretched plight
Nor saluage hart, but ruth of her sad plight
That his sad mother seeing his sore plight,
All wayes she sought, him to restore to plight,
In that foule plight a comely personage,
And eke their lately bruzed parts to bring in plight.
And he emongst the rest crept forth in sory plight.
Their tawney bodies, in their proudest plight:
Dissembling his disease and euill plight;
Well falles it thee that I am not in plight
Of th'euill plight, in which her dearest brother
Vnweeting of thine owne like haplesse plight:
Thy ruefull plight I pitty as mine owne.
And wast his wretched daies in wofull plight;
There he continued in this carefull plight,
And pitty much his plight, that liu'd like outcast thrall.
Who seeing his sad plight, her tender heart
Full of discomfort and disquiet plight,
With mild regard, to see his ruefull plight,
In heauy plight and sad perplexitie;
Which fayled oft through faint and feeble plight:
Is farre from hearing of my heauy plight;
In this sad plight he walked here and there,
For his deare sake, that ill deseru'd that plight:
To whom complayning her afflicted plight,
That Artegall him selfe her seemelesse plight did rew.
Which in the rudenesse of that euill plight,
Her to obay, sith he his faith had plight,
She chaw'd the cud of louers carefull plight;
For breach of faith to her, which he had firmely plight.
Me to deceiue of faith vnto me plight,
After that long daies toile and weary plight.
They might perceiue, she was not well in plight;
Whom leauing there in that dispiteous plight,
With piteous ruth of her so wretched plight,
Much was he moued with her piteous plight,
But sure to me her faith she first did plight,
Her halfe dismayd they found in doubtfull plight,
With so foule blame, as breach of faith once plight,
And cast his shield about, to be in readie plight.
his state and present plight.
Yet since he was not presently in plight
And being moou'd with pittie of my plight,
Is now him selfe in much more wretched plight;
And to salute him, if he were in plight,
Sir Calidore his faith thereto did plight,
There left on ground, though in full euill plight,
